subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: 1485 kHz
author: Zack Widup
full_text:
Hi Al,

Do you mean the 14 MHz (20 meter) band or 21 MHz (15 meter) band? 14 
meters was never allocated to radio amateurs. :-)

Until we get some more sunspots, 15 meters and above has been fairly dead 
for over a year. 20 meters has quite a bit of activity and 40 and 80 
meters get most of the activity these days.

1485 kHz is in the AM broadcast band but isn't a standard channel in the 
USA, which goes in 10 kHz steps. There would be stations on 1480 and 1490 
in the USA, not necesssarily in your area, though. If you go to this page:

http://www.fcc.gov/mb/audio/amq.html

Enter 1480 as the lower frequency and 1490 as the upper frequency and 
you'll get a page listing all the stations on those two frequencies.

Zack


On Wed, 19 Nov 2008, threadsintyme@... wrote:

> LOL...Same here! I *thought* that this sounded as if it were in the AM band.
> Glad I didn't ask if it was AM or FM or SSB! LOL hehe
> Man, I remember when I was a kid and would work DX on the 14 meter band. CW was my choice and really loved it. <sigh, heavy, heart broken sigh>
> That was back in the good ole daze of 1968...had more sick days at school that they kept up with!
> Al
>
> -- don powell <dpowell7299@...> wrote:
>
> According to Wikipedia, 1485 Khz is in the AM band region.  I had thought so but had to look it up.... really long time since my radio/antenna design days :)
>
> Don
>
> --- On Wed, 11/19/08, threadsintyme@... <Threadsintyme@...> wrote:
> From: threadsintyme@... <Threadsintyme@...>
> Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: 1485 kHz

> Jeff,
> I wonder what is on that frequency in the US?
> Al
>
> -- "Jeff" <vortex6066@yahoo. com.au> wrote:
>
> Hi Mike,
> My viewpoint on this is that 1485kHz was a frequency that provided
> Jurgenson with one (of probably many) correct combinations of
> frequency spectra and dynamics necessary for the formation of EVP -
> at that period in time, and at that location.
> In chapter 24 of "Sprechfunk mit Verstorbenen" , Jurgenson mentions
> that "Lena" used a special sound frequency that she fashioned from
> the overlapping of certain sounds and which would have sounded in
> most cases like a toneless, meaningless hissing.
> Also he mentions that the "friends" were able to shape the sound
> frequencies of the radio waves by instantly modulating the existing
> sounds.
> But most importantly, in chapter 43 he mentions being able to turn
> the radio dial carefully and hear Lena's voice on almost every
> frequency.
>
> I tend to conclude therefore that 1485khz was one of many useful
> frequencies he used that time, but probably holds no specific
> relevance today, excepting if it is able to provide the correct
> spectral dynamics (more than any other frequency).
> regards,
> JEFF
>
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com, "M.A. Coletta (Mike)"
> <michaelcoletta@ ...> wrote:
>>
>> So, what's up with the frequency 1485 kHz?
>>
>> - Mike (UFO Geek)
>> http://www.ufogeek. com
